abstractText: The present study examines a supply chain consisting of a manufacturer and a retailer. The manufacturer produces a product with a national brand (NB) and the retailer selling both the NB product and his own premium store brand (PSB) product. The manufacturer competes with the retailer through improving the quality by using innovation over time. It is assumed that both advertising and enhanced quality play positive roles in customers’ loyalty over time for the NB product. We propose four scenarios, including: (1) Decentralized (D), (2) Centralized (C), (3) Coordination with a revenue-sharing contract (RSH), and (4) Coordination with a two-part tariff contract (TPT). A Stackelberg differential game model is developed, and parametric analyses and managerial insights are provided based on a numerical example. Our results show that: (1) Introducing a PSB product alongside selling the NB product is profitable for the retailer, (2) In Scenario D and RSH, the manufacturer tries to increase the quality gap with the PSB product through innovation, (3) Customers’ loyalty leads to higher prices, levels of innovation, quality, and advertising for the NB product, (4) The TPT contract can lead to perfect coordination and yield higher profits for the manufacturer and the retailer.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text:
Supply chain (SC), as a connected network of suppliers, manufacturers, distributors, retailers, and customers, is one of the critical issues in today’s researches. There are various topics
B Morteza Rasti-Barzoki rasti@cc.iut.ac.ir
Parisa Assarzadegan assarzadegan@iut.ac.ir
Seyed Reza Hejazi rehejazi@cc.iut.ac.ir
1 Department of Industrial and Systems Engineering, Isfahan University of Technology, Isfahan 84156-83111, Iran
in Supply Chain Management (SCM) that can be addressed, such as product development, demand management, marketing and sales, logistic, production, Research and Development (R&D), and customer relationship management (Lambert & Enz, 2017). Introduction of Store Brand products (SBs) or Private Label products (PLs) plays a significant role in the profitability and decisions of SC’s members. The competition between National Brand products (NBs) and SB products in the SC and interactions of manufacturers and retailers have attracted the researchers’ attention (Assarzadegan & Hejazi, 2021; Cheng et al., 2021, 2022; Milberg et al., 2019; Niu et al., 2021; Tsafarakis et al., 2016; Zhang et al., 2021).
Private Label Manufacturers Association (PLMA, 2021) has reported that retailers tend to put SBs in a better position than NBs by offering high-quality products. Most countries have a market share of 30% or more for store brands, and the highest market shares can be found in Spain, Switzerland, and the UK (about 50% in each of these countries). With the growth of SBs, several large retailers such as Tesco, Walmart, Carrefour, and Safeway have introduced SBs in various categories. In today’s world, SBs exist in both food categories, including beverages, dry grocery, fresh and refrigerated foods, and non-food categories, including health and beauty, cosmetic, household, and auto aftercare_ENREF_127. Several articles in recent years have discussed the growth of SBs and their impact on the supply chain and retailing. “Annals of Operations Research” as one of the leading journals in this field, has published several articles on various topics such as competition between manufacturers and retailers in the supply chain with the presence of SBs and the effect of various contracts such as revenue-sharing, profit sharing, and two-part tariff contracts on the coordination between manufacturers and retailers (Amrouche et al., 2008).
There are three types of SBs, including Generic Store Brand products (GSBs), CopyCat Store Brand products, and Premium Store Brand products (PSBs). Gielens et al. (2021) introduced a new strategy for store brands called “Smart Store Brand” products (SSBs). They claimed that in the current marketplace, retailers should pay attention not only to price and quality, but also to issues such as sustainability, social responsibility, and ethics. Premium Store Brand products introduced into the market with unique packaging as a source of distinction follow such added value strategies as providing valuable products, increasing sales, improving margin gains, effecting prices close to or above those of NBs, and offering qualities equal or superior to those of NBs (Kumar, 2007). PSB examples are “President’s Choice” (for Loblaws), “Fior Fiore” (for Fior Fiore), “Sam’s Choice” (for Walmart), and “Tesco Finest” (for Tesco) (Elisa & Donata Tania, 2020).
According to Jacoby and Kyner (1973), brand loyalty is (1) non-random, (2) behavioral response (i.e., buying), (3) expressed over time, (4) described by some decision-making units according to one or more alternative brands, (5) is a function of psychological processes (decision-making and evaluation). Keller (1993) defined brand loyalty as "a favorable attitude towards a brand that leads to the sustainable purchase over time." Therefore, one of the factors in determining brand loyalty is the time factor.
Manufacturers in competition with retailers try to increase their customers loyalty over time through innovation, advertising, and high-quality products. They use innovation as a means of differentiation to improve loyalty and quality gaps with PSBs over time (Kumar, 2007). Brand loyalty leads to benefits such as reducing marketing costs, creating new customers, increasing market share and relative prices, reducing search motivation, and creating more loyal customers to competitive strategies (Chaudhuri & Holbrook, 2001).
Therefore, one of the most competitive advantages for manufacturers is having loyal customers. What are the ways to get these loyal customers? For example, “Kraft Heinz” company is a leading manufacturer in the food industry and is recognized as an innovative brand. The product innovation activities, including innovative packaging, providing healthy
products, and improving the product’s taste. On the other hand, the cost of advertising for Heinz has grown significantly in recent years. The company’s strategy to counter the entry of private labels is to introduce everyday low pricing programs (Gehlhar Mark et al., 2009). Also, Innocent drinks is a UK company that manufactures healthy drinks and smoothies. In 2009, “Coca-Cola” company invested Innocent. The activities in the product innovation, including using natural ingredients, sustainable packaging, and resource efficiency. For promotional purposes, the company uses television advertising, direct email advertising, online advertising, magazine, and outdoor advertising. On the other hand, Coca-Cola’s advertising is beneficial for Innocent drinks (Abbing, 2010).
Retailers also try to bring PSBs’ features closer to NBs by improving the quality over time. Let’s review a real-world example of the NB and PSB competition: Loblaws (the Canadian retailer) offers about 5000 SB products, and 30% of its sales are related to SBs. It has a premium store brand named “President’s Choice”, consisting of grocery products, financial, andmobile services. This premium store brand (“President’sChoice”) attractsmany customers and has gained significant loyal customers. The “President’s Choice” competes with National Brands and focuses on quality rather than price. For example, in the market of chocolate chip cookies, there are two brands: “Chips Ahoy!” (National Brand) and “The Decadent” under the label of “President’s Choice” (Premium Store Brand). “The Decadent” uses creamery butter and about 20%more chocolate chips than “ChipsAhoy!”. These features cause “TheDecadent” to be the leading brand inCanada’s chocolate chip cookies andovertake the “Chips Ahoy”.
Due to the COVID-19 and the economic crisis created in the world, the growth of SBs has increased significantly. Therefore, the competition between NB manufacturers and retailers has increased, and providing solutions to increase the coordination between NB manufacturers and retailers in the supply chain has been considered more than before. Unlike in the past that SBs had lower quality and price compared to NBs, in today’s world SBs compete with NBs in terms of quality. Therefore, NB manufacturers are required to use innovation and advertising to increase their profitability in order to increase the loyalty of their customers. Two issues of coordination between NB manufacturers and retailers and increasing the loyalty of NBs are important issues in SCM. On the other hand, one of the new and interesting topics in this field is the modeling of demand functions for NBs and SBs in SCM, considering important factors such as customer loyalty and designing coordination strategies between NB manufacturers and retailers dynamically.
Designing supply chain contracts (i.e., Revenue-Sharing, Two-Part Tariff, Profit-Sharing, etc.) for coordination between manufacturers and retailers is a new topic that has attracted the attention of researchers (Cheng et al., 2020; Fang et al., 2013; Huo, 2021; Li et al., 2018).
The present article tries to answer these research questions:
(1) What decisions does the manufacturer make over time for pricing, levels of advertising, and innovation for the NB product? What is the retailer pricing decision over time for PSB and NB products? (2) How is the competition between the NB manufacturer and the retailer with the introduction of the PSB product and considering the coordination contracts between them over time? (3) What effects does the design of RSH and TPT contracts have on the manufacturer’s decisions (levels of advertising, innovation, and the wholesale price) and the retailer decisions (NB and PSB retail prices)? Can contracts increase the profits of SCmembers?
(4) What effects do innovation and advertising have on customers’ loyalty to theNB product over time? Is customers’ loyalty profitable for themanufacturer?What about the retailer? Can the increase in customers’ loyalty lead to higher prices? (5) What effects does the introduction of a PSB product have on the decisions of SC members? Do the costs of producing a PSB product affect the competition between the NB and PSB products?
The key findings can be summarized as follows. First, the optimal decisions of NB’s and PSB’s pricing, levels of innovation, advertising are obtained over time. Second, we show that both the manufacturer and the retailer increase prices when customers’ loyalty rises over time. Third, the TPT contract can lead to perfect coordination, and the manufacturer’s and the retailer’s profits under the TPT contract are higher than the RSH contract.
The rest of this article is as follows. A literature review is provided in Sect. 2. The model and the related assumptions are defined in Sect. 3. Section 4 introduces four scenarios and the solution methods, and Sect. 5 presents analyses, the comparison between scenarios, and managerial implications. Conclusions are presented in Sect. 6.

sections.heading: 2 Literature review
sections.text:
Karray and Zaccour (2005) studied a SC with one manufacturer and a retailer with a SB. The authors modeled the problem as a differential game and studied the effects of introducing the SB product and cooperative advertising decisions.Martín-Herrán and Taboubi (2005) studied a supply chain including twomanufacturers (as the leaders) supplying two competitive brands and one retailer (the follower). They provided a Stackelberg differential game model and investigated decisions related to shelf space allocation and advertising. They concluded that advertising and shelf space allocation decisions were affected by the level of customers’ goodwill (toward both brands). Martín-Herrán et al. (2006) explored the decisions of shelf space and pricing for two competing brands. They provided a Stackelberg game model to obtain optimal decisions.
He et al. (2007) surveyed the Stackelberg differential game models used in marketing channels and SCM. Amrouche et al. (2008) formulated the problem of competition between aNBproduct and a store one as a differential gamemodel and provided Feedback-Stackelberg advertising and pricing strategies. Karray andMartín-Herrán (2009) used a differential game model for a channel with one manufacturer and a retailer who introduced a SB product to study decisions related to the pricing and advertising (both competitive and complementary). Palmeira and Thomas (2011) maintained that the simultaneous introduction of value and premium SBs would enhance the customer’s appraisal of the PSB’s quality.
Yue et al. (2013) analyzed a SC composed of a manufacturer and one retailer and studied optimal advertising and pricing decisions. They proposed the Profit-Sharing (PSH) contract to integrate SC. Chen (2015) investigated pricing and advertising decisions in a dual-channel SC. They considered two groups of consumers, including (1) manufacturer-loyal consumers (or brand-loyal consumers), (2) retailer-loyal (or store-loyal consumers), and addressed a game model. Li et al. (2016) provided a TPT contract to coordinate a dual-channel green SC and studied optimal pricing and greenness related to the green product. They also considered consumer loyalty to the retailer in their model. Hara and Matsubayashi (2017) proposed a game model based on Hotelling’s linear city model (Hotelling, 1990) to conclude that the production of multiple PSBs would guarantee the success of cooperation between one manufacturer and a retailer.
Chung and Lee (2017) proposed a SC with one (or two) manufacturer(s) and a retailer to investigate the quality positioning of NB and SB products. Mai et al. (2017) suggested three warranty contracts from the retailer to the manufacturer for SB products to motivate the manufacturer to enhance the SBs’ quality. Chung and Lee (2018) conducted an empirical investigation to study the effects of introducing SBs on pricing policies. They discovered that the SB introduction changed the structure of price leadership. Li et al. (2018) suggested a Stackelberg game model examine the effects of Money-Back Guarantee (MBG) offered for NBs and SBs. They proposed a coordination contract to create win–win conditions for both the retailer and the manufacturer.
Huang and Feng (2020) examined a SC including one manufacturer and a retailer with its own SB product. They considered different MBG policies for both brands and used game models to determine pricing decisions. Zhao et al. (2020) addressed a SC with a common retailer and two manufacturers. They assumed that manufacturers sell substitutable products to the retailer under the RSH contract and decide pricing and shelf space strategies. They provided three game models (Nash, Stackelberg, and collusion) to solve the problem. Bart et al. (2020) reviewed articles that used RSH contracts in SCs and studied the future trend of RSH contracts in operations management.
Liu et al. (2020) studied a Cost-Sharing contract to coordinate a SC and used a Stackelberg gamemodel to examine optimal pricing decisions and the supplier’s effort performance. Khorshidvand et al. (2021) developed three models, including Centralized SC (CSC), Decentralized SC (DSC), and Modified Centralized SC (MCSC) in a multi-channel SC. They applied a Stackelberg game model to investigate decisions of greenness, pricing, and advertising. Cheng et al. (2021) investigated the SB introduction effect on a three-echelon SC and concluded that the SB introduction is profitable for SC’s members. Pei et al. (2021) proposed two coordination strategies in online-to-offline retailing, including quantity discount to the retailer and a rebate to customers. They addressed a Stackelberg game model to examine pricing decisions in both online and offline channels.
Song et al. (2021) developed a Stackelberg differential game model and investigated pricing and innovation efforts over time in a decentralized and centralized SC with one buyer and one seller. Huo (2021) reviewed the mechanism of SC coordination in the presence of SBs in five categories, including advertising, channel coordination, rebate and promotion strategies, shelf space allocation, and contracts. He also addressed a Stackelberg differential game model to investigate the information-sharing scenarios of advertising costs related to NBandSBproducts.Al-Monawer et al. (2021) studied a SCwith amanufacturer and a retailer that sells both NB and SB products. They formulated the problem as a game theoretic model to study the effect of the NB’s and SB’s customer bases on the manufacturer’s willingness to collaborate with the retailer for the SB introduction, pricing, and quality decisions of NB and SB products. They concluded that when the SB’s customer base is large, the manufacturer’s willingness to collaborate is more.
Shen et al. (2022) used a game-theoretic model to study the pricing of NB and SB under two contracts including wholesale and agency. They determined the equilibrium decisions of advertising and pricing forNB and SBproducts. Their results showed that the retailer prefer to introduceSBsunder thewholesale contract and the agency contract increases the retailer’s and the manufacturer’s profits. Zhang and Hou (2022) studied a SC with a NB manufacturer and an e-tailer that introduces its own SB. They considered two sales modes including reselling and agency selling and compared their environmental performance. They concluded that the manufacturer (e-tailer) favors reselling (agency selling) for the high percentage fee. Karray and Martín-Herrán (2022) studied a SC with two NB manufacturers and a retailer that can offers its ownSBs. They considered decision timing for advertising and pricing and developed
a Stackelberg gamemodel. Their findings suggest that if NBmanufacturers determine pricing decisions before advertising, the SB introduction for the retailer is detrimental.
Huang et al. (2022) addressed a SC including a NB manufacturer and a retailer with its own SB and considered two formats for disclosure of quality information including retailer disclosure and manufacturer disclosure. They showed that the SB introduction causes the manufacturer to disclose quality information conservatively and the retailer only reveal quality information if he introduces the SB and the SB. Li et al. (2022) used a game theoretic approach to analyze a SC with one manufacturer and one retailer that has its own SB. They studied SB encroachment strategies for the retailer and concluded that the PSB introduction improves consumers’ welfare and channel profit. Hsiao et al. (2022) examined a SC with one NB manufacturer and a retailer that offers its own SB. They concluded that when the NB manufacturer supplies the SB product to the retailer, both the manufacturer and the retailer benefit from revealing the supplier information. But, if the SB is manufactured by a third party, both the manufacturer and the retailer adjust a non-disclosure strategy.

sections.heading: 2.1 Research gap and contributions
sections.text:
According to the reviewed articles, two issues are not addressed in the literature review: First, the number of articles that considered contract design in the competition between NB manufacturers and retailers for NB and PSB products is limited. In the researches of Li et al. (2018) and Huang and Feng (2020), the impact of the MBG contract on NB and PSB pricing and coordination ofmanufacturers and retailerswere investigated. The contracts such asRSH, TPT, CSH, etc., can lead to supply chain coordination and increase cooperation between manufacturers and retailers. We proposed four scenarios for the supply chain, including (1) Decentralized, (2) Centralized, (3) Coordinationwith aRSH contract, (4) Coordinationwith a TPT contract to study the impacts of contracts on competition betweenNB and PSB products.
Second, among the articles on competition between NB and PSB products, there is no article on modeling customers’ loyalty to the NB product over time, while customers’ loyalty is one of the most important and influential factors in manufacturers’ decisions. Also, in articles such as Karray and Zaccour (2005), Karray and Martín-Herrán (2009), Amrouche et al. (2008), and Huo (2021), the time factor is taken into account in pricing and advertising decisions of SBs and NBs. But so far, no research has considered the time factor in modeling customers’ loyalty.
Third, in the previous studies, the coordination contracts between NB manufacturers and retailerswere studied statically. In this study,we formulated the demand functions for bothNB and SB products dynamically and examined the impacts of coordination contracts including RSH and TPT on pricing, loyalty, levels of innovation, and advertising dynamically. Also, a dynamic quality function considering innovation was presented for the first time in this paper and modeled as one of the factors influencing customer loyalty over time.
In the present study, for the first time, the customers’ loyalty function to the NB product is modeled over timewith innovation and advertising as its parameters.Moreover, a Stackelberg differential game model is proposed for problem-solving.
Table 1 shows the related research gap among previous studies. The main contributions of this paper are as follows:
• The influence of innovation on the NB’s quality is considered over time, and a quality function is formulated based on innovation over time. In the quality function, it is assumed that innovation increases the quality over time. It helps manufacturers to consider innovation, improve the quality, and increase the quality gaps with SB products.

sections.heading: 3.2 Problem definition
sections.text:
Suppose a SC with a manufacturer and one retailer who promotes a PSB product. The wholesale price for the manufacturer’s product is w(t), and the retailer’s prices for the NB product and thePSBproduct are pN B(t) and pP SB(t), respectively. TheNBandPSBproducts are substitutable. The manufacturer to compete with the retailer, tries to increase the loyalty of its customers through innovation (μ(t)) and advertising (A (t)) over time. The retailer will also increase the PSB demand by introducing a high-quality (qP SB ) product to compete with the NB product.
It is supposed that the manufacturer’s product initial quality is q0N B , and the manufacturer improves the quality through innovation. They concluded that if the RSH contract implemented, the loser is the retailer. Mai et al. sections.heading: 4.4 Scenario TPT: coordination of the supply chain with a two-part tariff contract

A Two-Part Tariff is a form of pricing wherein the product’s price consists of two parts including, a lump-sum fee as well as a per-unit charge (Hayes, 1987). Yang et al.

sections.heading: 5.1 Numerical results
sections.text:
The following numerical example is provided for the proposed problem. Table 3 reports the values for the parameters involved. Some of the data such as NB and PSB market bases (α1, α2), self-price elasticity of NB and PSB (β1, β2), cross-price elasticity (b1), and NB and PSB production costs (cN B , cP SB ) are provided from (Kurata et al., 2007), and other parameters are estimated close to real-world data.
The state variables obtained by solving differential equations for the above example in four scenarios are summarized in Table 4.

The parametric and numerical solutions in all four scenarios are given in Table 5. In order to ensure the robustness of the presented model, 10 numerical examples were solved with different values for α1, α2, β1, β2, cN B , cP SB , and the answers for all four scenarios are given in Table A1 in the Appendix. The results obtained are as follows:
• The NB loyalty value in scenario C and TPT is higher than the other two scenarios for different values of parameters. This shows that the two-part tariff contract ismore profitable for the NB manufacturer than the revenue-sharing contract. • The value of innovation and advertising in scenario C and TPT is higher than the other two scenarios for different values of parameters. On the other hand, the wholesale price of NB product in scenario D is higher than scenarios C and TPT in different examples. • The retail price of NB and PSB products in the revenue-sharing contract is lower than other scenarios. Therefore, under different values of the parameters, the profitability of the retailer under the revenue-sharing contract is lower than others. • When the PSB’s production cost is higher than the NB’s production cost (cP SB > cN B ), or when the price sensitivity to the PSB product is lower than that of the NB product (β1 > β2), the PSB’s retail price is higher than the NB’s retail price. • In different parameter values, the retail price of PSB product is higher than the wholesale price of NB product for scenarios C and TPT. Also, the retail price of the NB product in scenario D is higher than others.

sections.heading: 5.2 Discussion results andmanagerial insights
sections.text:
Result 1 According to Figs. 5 and 6, the manufacturer increases advertising and innovation over time in all scenarios. Therefore, the increase in advertising and innovation of the NB product leads to an increase in customers’ loyalty over time (Fig. 7).
Managerial insight 1 Manufacturers believe that one of the most important ways to deal with the PLs’ growth is to use innovation and advertising constantly. For example, “Kraft Heinz”, as a national brand, has a strong focus on innovation and advertising to counter the success of PLs such as “President’s Choice” (for Loblaws) and “Tesco” (for Tesco). Manufacturers increase levels of innovation and advertising over time. By increasing innovation, quality, and advertising over time, the brand image in customers’ mind improves and leads to the increase in their loyalty to the brand over time.
Grönroos (2000) also concluded that enhancing the quality over time will increase customer retention, sales, and profits. On the other hand, the TPT contract yields higher innovation, advertising, and loyalty over time. One of the advertising strategies for NBs is social media channels. The NB manufacturers can increase the loyalty of their customers through advertising on social networks such as Facebook, Instagram, and YouTube. For
Table 5 Summary of the results
Fig. 7 NB loyalty over time under various scenarios
example, “Starbucks” has invested in social networks in recent years to switch from traditional advertising channels and in 2018, won silver IPA Effectiveness award for its social strategy.
Examining brand loyalty over time by considering the factors of innovation and advertising for national brands, as well as by considering revenue-sharing and two-part tariffs contracts over time, is one of the main contributions of this article.
Result 2 According to Figs. 8 and 9, the retailer increases the NB’s and PSB’s retail prices over time. Also, when the manufacturer and the retailer determine their decisions separately (Scenario D), the retailer considers a higher price for the NB product. However, when the manufacturer and the retailer determine their decisions integrated (ScenarioC) and participate in TPT contract (Scenario TPT), the PSB’s price is higher than other scenarios.
Managerial insight 2 As customers’ loyalty to the NB product increases over time, competitive pressure to reduce prices decreases, which in turn causes increase in the NB’s price over time. It is a common and real-world experience that customers are willing to pay more for
their favorite brands. For example, in the packaged coffee category, there are several brands including, “Flogers”, “Douwe Egberts”, and “Maxwell House”. The price competition in these brands is high, but why are customers willing to pay $3 for a cup of “Starbucks” coffee? The answer to this question is that “Starbucks” has loyal customers visiting “Starbucks” Café 20 times a month.
One of the most important factors in increasing loyalty in today’s market is “customer experience”. It means that customers are willing to pay more if they receiving great experience, even up to a 16% price premium. Using Artificial Intelligence (AI) to enhance customer experience is a successful solution. For example, “Nestlé” uses a chatbot for delivering special offers, and “PepsiCo” uses self-driving robots to deliver food.
Managerial insight 3 Increasing loyalty over time allows both the manufacturer and the retailer to eke out their profits. The retailer also uses increasing customers’ loyalty over time as a competitive advantage and increases the PSB’s price. The introduction of a PSB allows the retailer to gain more profits. For example, Tesco (the British retailer) sells 100 g of milk chocolate under the premium store brand “Tesco Finest” more expensive than (£1.3) 110 g of milk chocolate under the national brand “Cadbury” (£1). Therefore, as in the real-world cases, increasing loyalty leads to increasing prices, the modeling presented in this article also shows that loyalty is an important factor in increasing prices.
Result 3 According to Fig. 10, as cN B (the production cost of NB product) rises, the manufacturer decreases the levels of innovation in all scenarios over time, but as cP SB (the production cost of PSB product) rises, the manufacturer increases the level of innovation over time (Fig. 11).
Managerial insight 4Themanufacturer reacts to increasing the production cost ofNBproduct by reducing innovation, and thereby decreasing its quality over time. In contrast, in reaction to the increased production cost of the PSB product, themanufacturer enhances the quality by
Fig. 12 Effect of γ1 on the NB’s price over time under various scenarios
Fig. 13 Effect of γ2 on the PSB’s price over time under various scenarios
increasing innovation over time. It means that the manufacturer is trying to raise the quality gap with the PSB product over time.
Result 4 According to Fig. 12, as γ1 increases, the retailer increases the price of NB product over time and the price increase in scenarios C and TPT is higher than others. Figure 13 shows that with the increase of γ2 over time, the price of the PSB product also increases, and this increase is more in C and TPT scenarios than in other scenarios.
Managerial insight 5 By increasing the effect of NB loyalty on its demand and on the other hand, increasing the effect of PSB’ quality on its demand, the retailer can charge a higher price for both brands. This shows the importance of customer loyalty for NBs and the product quality for SBs in pricing. In other words, retailers charge higher prices over time for highquality SBs and NBs with high customer loyalty.
Result 5 As you can see in Figs. 14, 15 and 16, as β1 increases over time, the NBmanufacturer decreases the levels of innovation, advertising, and price for NB product, respectively. This shows that the sensitivity of customers to the price can force the NB manufacturer to reduce
Fig. 15 Effect of β1 on the levels of advertising over time under various scenarios
Fig. 16 Effect of β1 on the NB’s price over time under various scenarios
the level of innovation and advertising for the NB product, and as a result, the price of the product will decrease.
Managerial insight 6 As the price sensitivity of the demand for the NB product increases, the NB manufacturer is forced to reduce the cost of the product, and since the costs related to innovation and advertising are influential in product pricing, with the increase of the customers’ sensitivity to the price, the NB manufacturer reduces the level of innovation and advertising so that by reducing the costs related to innovation and advertising, the NB product’s total cost will reduce, and consequently the final price of the NB product will also decrease.
Result 6 As you can see in Figs. 17 and 18, the retailer increases the NB’s and PSB’s retail prices over time by rising the PSB’s production cost. This shows that one of the influential parameters in the pricing of national and store brands is the PSB production cost. On the other hand, the NB’s retail price under the decentralized scenario and the PSB’ retail price under the two-part tariff contract are higher than other scenarios.
Managerial insight 7 One of the factors influencing the retailer’s pricing decision is the PSB’s production cost over time. As the PSB’s cost is increased over time, the retailer raises the PSB’s and NB’s selling prices. The retailer will try to compensate for the increased production cost of its own brand through the greater earnings made from increased prices
Fig. 18 Effect of cP SB on the PSB’s price over time under various scenarios
of NB and PSB products. Therefore, managing the PSB’s production costs over time is an important issue that plays a crucial role in supply chain pricing decisions. There are various ways of producing premium store brand products, such as outsourcing, produce by retailers, cooperationwithmanufacturers, etc. Choosing the appropriate productionmethod to produce PSB products at affordable production costs can affect supply chain performance.
There are dedicated SBs manufacturers (“Cott Corporation”, “McBride”, “Aegle Nutrition”, etc.) that manufacturer SBs at high volumes and low margins. For example, “Aegle Nutrition” offers low cost, high quality, short lead-time, and full service SB manufacturing. “Walmart”, “CVSpharmacy”, “Walgreens”, “Whole Foods” and “Unfi” are among its clients.
Result 7 According to Proposition 9, the lower and upper bound for the manufacturer’s and the retailer’s profit under TPT contract are shown in Figs. 19 and 20, respectively. As it is clear in the figures, both the NB manufacturer’s profit and the retailer’s profit are higher in the centralized scenario than other scenarios. Also, scenario D for the NB manufacturer and scenario RSH for the retailer bring the lowest profitability.
Managerial insight 8 The centralized SC is more profitable for both the retailer and the manufacturer. As mentioned, under this scenario, the PSB’s price, the NB’s advertising,
innovation, and the profits of themanufacturer and the retailer are higher than other scenarios. If Scenario C is not practical, the TPT contract can lead to perfect coordination and yield higher profits for the retailer and the manufacturer than the RSH contract.

sections.heading: 5.3 Comparison
sections.text: In this section, our model is compared with other existing similar models. As you can see in Table 6, in the literature review, advertising and pricing have been the two main issues, and the modeling of the concepts raised in this article, i.e., quality, innovation, and loyalty, and formulating them as a function of time, has been presented for the first time.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion
sections.text:
A supply chain was presented in this paper that involved a manufacturer and one retailer who offered a PSB alongside the NB product. The manufacturer enhanced customer loyalty over time not only through advertising but also by using innovation. The retailer also competed with themanufacturer by introducing its own high-quality product. Studying the NB and PSB competition by considering customers’ loyalty over time in the supply chain is a novel aspect of the paper. We developed four scenarios for the supply chain, including (1) Decentralized, (2) Centralized, (3) Coordination with the RSH contract, and (4) Coordination with the TPT contract. Our results indicated that under the two-part tariff contract, the levels of innovation, advertising, and NB’s and PSB’s price are more than the revenue-sharing. On the other hand, the NB manufacturer’s and the retailer’s profits under the two-part tariff contract are higher than the revenue-sharing contract.
A Stackelberg differential game model was then proposed for solving the problem. The optimal decisions of manufacturer on pricing, innovation, and advertising as well as those of the retailer on pricing, were also taken into account. A numerical example, as well as parametric analyses and managerial insights, were presented. For the first time, the NB loyalty’s behavior over time was shown in this paper, and decision variables related to the NB product including levels of innovation, advertising, and pricing were obtained over time for four scenarios. Also, the PSB’s price was obtained over time for all scenarios.
Our results indicated that brand loyalty plays a significant role in themanufacturer’s and the retailer’s decisions in SC. Brand loyalty increases prices, the manufacturer’s and the retailer’s profits, as in the real world, brand-loyal consumers are willing to pay more to buy the brand they want. Also, the results indicate that the manufacturer is trying to widen the quality gap with the PSB product through innovation in Scenario D and Scenario RSH. The limitations of our paper are as follows: (1) The NB loyalty function is considered to be linear, and other forms (logarithmic, power, etc.) of the loyalty function may be considered for future work. (2) We assume that the retailer introduces a PSB product alongside the NB product it will be interesting to considermultiple retailers with different store brands (generic, copycat, premium, and smart). (3) The effect of advertising and innovation on NB loyalty is considered in this paper, addressing other factors such as trust and brand image is also a suggestion for future work. (4) In this article, it is assumed that the manufacturer sells the NB product to the retailer, in the real-life, it is likely to sell the products through both the online and retail channels. (5) We formulated the NB’s loyalty over time considering innovation and advertising, formulating the loyalty function of PSB product, considering factors such as quality, greenness, retailer credibility, etc., is an attractive topic for future research.
